BriefingText:
BRIEFING

Welcome to Project Apollo, the most advances spaceship to-date. The spacecraft has many complex systems that work together to provide navigation and life-support for three astronauts for long-duration missions in space.

Don't feel overwhelmed by the amount of switches and systems, it will all make sense in the end. And you will have access to checklists.

This lesson will teach you the final preparations before launch and the boost phase. We will go through the Computer and the systems needed for a safe ascent. However, the mission will end before the launch.
Description:
Welcome to Project Apollo! This spacecraft is far more advanced and complex than both Project Mercury and Project Gemini and will take a lot of studying to master.
These lessons are designed to give you the basic understanding of its systems.

MissionCommands.Message: Welcome to Apollo, and Launch Complex 39 here at Cape Canaveral! This is in a very early development and is subject to many changes. Most systems are in an early implementation stage.
You are now sitting inside the Apollo Block II Command Module. It is attached to a Service Module where most of the major life support equipment is installed.
The Command and Service Module (CSM) combo is the primary Apollo spacecraft. It is sitting on top of a 111 meter high rocket named The Saturn V, whom is currently being prepared for launch.
The CSM is a highly sophisticated spacecraft with both manual and automatic systems that are designed to take you safely to the Moon and back.

Hold down the mouse wheel button while draging the mouse to look around, or in case you have configures the input, use your settings. Use the arrow keys and PAGE UP/PAGE DN to move the camera manually.
The primary source of power are three Fuel Cells, with batteries installed as backup (or during high power demands).
The Command Module can host three astronauts, each with a primary duty. In this simulator, you assume control of all systems.
The left seat is the commanders seat. Use the [V]iew Menu or press [F5] to set the camera into this seat. It's primary view is the attitude controls, entry monitoring and sequencer control.
The middle seat [F6] is the command module pilot view and has the computer, environmental control and attitude controls.
The right seat is the Lunar Module pilot [F7] with view of the electrical systems, radio control and SPS engine configuration panel.
There are much more to each seat but this is a general description.
[F9] will move the camera to the left seat window and [F10] will move it to the right seat window.
The Command Module has a very sophisticated general purpose computer and is seen in the center/left panel. [F11] will move the camera to this view.
Most of the panels and controls are illuminated with both flood lights and fluorescent controlled from the left side of the left seat (Panel 8) and right side of the right seat (Panel 5).
Each panel is numbered to make it easier to locate switches and controls.
Now, most of the systems has already been set up for launch but there are a few important steps you need to perform. Using [M], you have access to the MISSION PAD.
From the CHECKLISTS menu on the MISSION PAD, look at the BOOST PREPARATIONS checklist. It can look quite daunting, but in reality it's quite quick.
I assume you don't touch anything on any of the panels unless you really know what you are doing, almost every switch is functional and will configure a system.
The first thing we need to do is to run Program 01 on the Apollo Guidance Computer located on MDC-2 (Main Display Console 2 aka. Panel 2).
The computer is operated by using VERBs and NOUNs. Each is identified with a numeric code.
To run Program 01 on the computer, first press VERB.
To change the program running, you use verb 37 to enter the program selection mode, then use a noun to select what program to run.
As you pressed VERB, the Apollo Guidance Computer (AGC) is waiting for input. Click on 3.
Followed by 7.
Then click ENTR to commit the AGC command.
The numerics are showing 37 and flashing, indicating it is waiting for more input. This is the noun. When you pressed ENTR after inserting 37, it automatically knows you will enter a noun next.
Click 0 on the keyboard (known as DSKY).
Then click 1 on the DSKY.
Then press ENTR once again on the DSKY to commit the AGC command.
Good. The AGC is now showing 01 on the upper right digit, indicating it is running program 01.
Program 01 will align the Inertial System and automatically run Program 02 when ready. While P01 is running the FDAI on MDC-1 will roll to the correct launch attitude.

Program 02 will fine align the inertial systems until liftoff. When the rocket detects that it is released from the launchpad, the AGC will receive a signal and automatically run program 11 - the boost program.

Program 11 is critical for the boost phase so, if for some reason, Program 11 won't start, you will do this manually. As we are discussing the AGC, I will explain how now, but this is usually a later step in the BOOST PREPARATION checklist.

A shortcut to do this exists if this is detected, and is done through V75E. Don't press anything yet, but what this means is that you need to press VERB, then 7, then 5, then ENTER to commit the AGC command.
It is very hard to press anything on the console during launch as the vibrations are on the extreme levels. It is therefore important to prepare for this before the countdown.
To do this, you will just before launch enter VERB, then 7 and then 5, but NOT press ENTER.
If for some reason Program 11 don't start when you are released from the launch pad, all you need to do is to press the ENTR button. We will do this soon.
Now that Program 02 is running on the computer, we can continue with the boost preparations. First thing we do is to distribute the electricity among the 16 Reaction Control System (RCS) thrusters.
Look left on Panel 8. A long horizontal set of switches named the AUTO RCS SELECT switches can be found. This can connect a thruster to either Main Bus A or Main Bus B, or disable it.
These are grouped into what a given thruster is assigned to do. First two groups are all thrusters used for rolling, then the third is for pitch and lastly the forth for yaw. Verify that A1 is OFF.
Verify that C1 is OFF.
Verify that A2 is OFF.
Verify that C2 is OFF.
Next roll group, verify that B1 is set to MNA.
Verify that D1 is set to MNB.
Verify that B2 is set to MNA.
Verify that D2 is set to MNB.
Then the pitch group, verify that A3 is set to MNB.
Verify that C3 is set to MNA.
Verify that A4 is set to MNA.
Verify that C4 is set to MNB.
Then the last yaw group, verify that B3 is set to MNA.
Verify that D3 is set to MNB.
Verify that B4 is set to MNB.
and check that D4 is set to MNA.

Let's also check Battery C. Battery C is important and is used for many of the important electrical systems during failures. Rotate the DC selection knob on MDC-3 to BAT C and check that the voltage is 37-37.5 vdc.
The voltage of the selected DC source can be seen in the DC VOLTS gauge. Rotate the DC Selector knob to Main Bus A.

A Flight Director & Attitude Indicator (FDAI) is used to see your attitude, errors and rates based on a stable platform. The one on MDC-1 should now display a pitch of 90, yaw of 0 and roll of 90 + the configures AZimuth.
Set the FDAI scale to 5/5. This is how sensitive the FDAI will be. We will now enable some maneuvering systems so they are easily useable in-case of an abort.
Set the RATE to HIGH. This will allow a faster angular rate during manual maneuvering.
Enable the translation stick by setting the TRANS CONTR PWR to up.
Set the Rotational Hand Control Direct Power 1 to MNA/MNB.
Set the Rotational Hand Control Direct Power 2 to MNA/MNB.
Set the Command Module Computer mode to FREE.
Then we will set the BAMGs to RATE 1. The BMAGS are used for backup attitude source, and for angular rates. Set BMAG ROLL to RATE 1.
Set BMAG PITCH to RATE 1.
Set BMAG YAW to RATE 1.
Then we will do an Astro Launch Operations Voice Check. Set the Lunar Module Pilot S BAND switch to OFF.
Set the Commander VHF AM switch to OFF.
Use the COMMUNICATION menu (keyboard button [C]) to do a RADIO CHECK.
Set the Lunar Module Pilot S BAND switch to T/R.
Set the Commander VHF AM switch to T/R.
Then do another RADIO CHECK to check the radio communication with MCCH.
Now ensure the Service Propulsion System engine is set to OFF by first verifying that the SPS THRUST switch on MDC-1 is NORMAL.
And that the two delta V THRUST switches is OFF, still on MDC-1.
Verify the a/PC IND switch on MDC-1 is set to a.
Check that EDS AUTO, 2 ENG OUT and LV RATES on MDC-2 is UP/AUTO. These are systems used to detect an abort.
Set the TVC SERVO PWR #1 to AC1/MNA
Set the TVC SERVO PWR #2 to AC2/MNB
Set the Fuel Cell Reaction Valve to LATCH. This will ensure the valve is maintained in the set position even during high vibration phases such as boost.
Verify the secondary coolant loop pump to OFF.
At T -04:10, the 5 L/V ENGINE lights should come on, indicating that they are armed but not thrusting.
Verify that Program 02 is running
Insert V75 into the computer as discussed earlier, but do NOT press ENTR!
The Primary Glycol to Radiator handle on Panel 325 is set to bypass (not yet implemented).
Set the Main Bus Tie A/C switch to ON.
Set the Main Bus Tie B/C switch to ON.
Set the two PAD COMM switches on the CNR and LMP radio panels of OFF.
Then the GDC needs to be aligned with the IMU. This is done by clicking on the GDC Align pushbutton on MDC-1.

This can be indicated by looking at the second FDAI on MDC-2. It should show the same total attitude as the FDAI on MDC-1. FDAI 1 is primarly using the IMU as the data source, while FDAI 2 is using the backup GDC platform as the total attitude source.

The spacecraft should now be set up for launch. This concludes the tutorial, good job - I know there are many systems involved so don't stress if you didn't understand most of these yet. Press ESC and End Session to return to the main menu.

Title: Apollo Lesson 1 - Pre-Launch
